quantityRules.description: Pacman frogs are cannibalistic and MUST be housed alone. Female frogs need minimum 40 gallons (36√ó18√ó18"), males need minimum 20 gallons (30√ó12√ó12"), juveniles can start in 10 gallons until 6-7 months old.

humidity.notes: C. cranwelli (Cranwell's) tolerate slightly lower humidity (more arid habitat). C. cornuta (Surinam) prefer higher humidity (rainforest habitat). Maintain with moist substrate and regular misting.

careTargets.gradient: Horizontal thermal gradient with warm side 80-85¬∞F and cool side 70-75¬∞F

adultSize: 3-7 inches diameter (females larger than males, varies by species)
temperament: Sedentary ambush predator, can be defensive and bite
originRegion: South America (Gran Chaco, Amazon basin - varies by species)
setupTips: Deep substrate essential (2-3" minimum for juveniles, 4-6" for adults) - frogs must be able to completely burrow
Overhead heating with halogen or incandescent bulbs provides best quality heat (short wavelength IR)
Water dish must accommodate full body soaking but be shallow enough frog can't fully submerge (poor swimmers)
All water must be treated with reptile/amphibian dechlorinator (chlorine causes toxic shock)
C. cranwelli require sandy substrate: 60% organic topsoil + 40% play sand to replicate Gran Chaco habitat
Leaf litter on substrate surface is critical - prevents substrate ingestion, provides CUC habitat
Modified bin enclosures acceptable for quarantine/grow-out but CANNOT be used with UVB (plastic creates toxins)
Substrate must be moist but not waterlogged - squeeze test: water should drip out but no puddles
notes: Named 'Pacman' frogs due to round body shape and large mouth resembling the classic video game character
'Horns' above eyes are actually bony projections - help camouflage as leaf litter when buried and may protect eyes from struggling prey
Possess odontoid projections (tooth-like structures on upper jaw) - not true teeth but create vice-grip preventing prey escape once bitten
Can consume prey up to 70% of their own body size - documented eating mice, small birds, other frogs, and even attempting to eat items larger than themselves
Enter estivation (underground dormancy) during dry season - create waterproof cocoon of shed skin layers and can survive buried without food for 6-12 months

warnings.message: SOLITARY SPECIES ONLY - Pacman frogs are cannibalistic. Never house two frogs together under any circumstances.
WATER TREATMENT MANDATORY - All water (substrate, dish, misting) must be treated with dechlorinator. Chlorine causes toxic shock syndrome which is often fatal.
LEG TWITCHING/STRETCHING - This is a sign of serious health issues including sepsis. Soak frog in tepid dechlorinated water (change every 15-20 min) and contact vet immediately.
NEVER USE: Coil UVB bulbs (uneven spread), Mercury Vapor bulbs (too hot), LED UVA/UVB combo bulbs (produce dangerous UVC radiation causing skin/eye injury).

SCREEN ENCLOSURES INAPPROPRIATE - Screen enclosures cause rapid moisture loss making it nearly impossible to maintain required 65-85% humidity. Use glass or PVC enclosures with partial ventilation. If using glass with screen top, cover 50-75% of screen with plastic wrap or acrylic.
SUBSTRATE REQUIRED - Paper towels, moss-only, bark, or foam prevent natural burrowing behavior. Use only for quarantine/illness/transport.
OVERHEAD HEATING PREFERRED - Heat lamps provide short wavelength IR that penetrates tissues for better digestion. Heat mats/CHEs/DHPs provide long wavelength IR (less effective).
AVOID OVERFEEDING - Obesity is common. Feed juveniles daily/every other day, adults every 7-10 days. Offer as much as frog eats in 10-15 minutes.
VET CARE ESSENTIAL - Establish care with amphibian-experienced vet within first few months. Annual checkups recommended. Don't wait for emergency.

DIMMER THERMOSTATS REQUIRED - Heat lamps and DHPs need dimming thermostats (not on/off). Flashing disrupts circadian rhythm and causes premature bulb failure. Use manual dimmer + on/off thermostat backup if budget-limited.
NIGHTTIME DARKNESS REQUIRED - Do NOT use blue/red/purple 'moonlight' bulbs. Frogs can see these lights. Use total darkness for healthy day/night cycle.
ANGRY RED UNDERSIDE - If severe with sores, indicates infection. Move to quarantine enclosure and contact vet. Slight pinkness when active is normal.

feedingRequirements: Obligate carnivores - whole prey items only (insects, worms, occasional rodents/fish)
Feeder size rule: width should not exceed distance between frog's eyes
Gutload all insects 24-48 hours before feeding for optimal nutrition
NEVER FEED: Red wiggler earthworms (toxic), goldfish/minnows (thiaminase), Pac Attack commercial food (plant fillers), beef/pork/chicken (nutritionally incomplete)
feedingSchedule: Froglets: Daily or every other day
As frog ages: decrease frequency, increase portion size
Safe feeding method: Offer as much as frog eats within 10-15 minutes
feedingVariety: STAPLES (rotate regularly): Dubia/discoid/red runner roaches, crickets, locusts, hornworms, nightcrawler earthworms, silkworms, black soldier fly larvae
OCCASIONAL (once monthly max): Whole rodents, chicks, guppies/mollies/platies/silversides, shrimp
TREATS (high fat): Mealworms, superworms, waxworms, butterworms
EMERGENCY BACKUP: Canned/preserved insects (snails, shrimp, crickets, grasshoppers) - less enriching but nutritionally adequate
supplementSchedule: WITHOUT UVB: Dust with calcium + D3 most feedings, multivitamin + D3 every 3-4 feedings
WITH UVB: Dust with calcium (no D3) most feedings, multivitamin (no D3) every 3-4 feedings, multivitamin WITH D3 every 7-8 feedings
Rodents/fish feeders: Do NOT dust (bones and organs provide complete nutrition)
waterNotes: Provide shallow water dish for full-body soaking
Water depth: Frog should sit with body under water but NOT fully submerge (poor swimmers)
All water must be treated with reptile/amphibian dechlorinator
Change water daily - frogs often defecate in water dish
handlingNotes: Minimal handling only - amphibians not meant for regular handling
When necessary: Wear moistened nitrile gloves (prevent skin oil transfer)
Keep fingers away from mouth - strong bite reflex
Frogs may jump - be careful of falls/escape
substrateMixing: TROPICAL SPECIES (C. ornata, C. cornuta): 100% coco fiber OR organic topsoil
ARID SPECIES (C. cranwelli): 60% organic topsoil + 40% play sand (washed sandbox sand)
BIOACTIVE: Josh's Frogs ABG Mix or BioDude Terra Firma (expensive but indefinite lifespan with CUC)
Substrate replacement: Coco fiber every 3-4 weeks, ReptiSoil every 2-3 months, bioactive with CUC = never (top off 1-2x yearly)
commonIssues: Buried for long time: Normal behavior (ambush predators). Will emerge when hungry. May brumate for weeks/months in winter.
Won't eat: Check temperature (must be 80-85¬∞F warm side), allow settling period if new (few days), try different feeders (picky eaters common), some prefer not being watched
Red underside with sores: Severe infection - contact vet immediately and move to quarantine
Leg twitching/stretching: Medical emergency (sepsis risk) - soak in tepid dechlorinated water and contact vet

speciesNotes.cranwelli: Cranwell's Horned Frog - Gran Chaco region. Prefers sandy substrate (60% soil/40% sand) and slightly lower humidity (65-75%). More arid adapted.
speciesNotes.cornuta: Surinam Horned Frog - Amazon rainforest. Prefers higher humidity (75-85%) and warmer temperatures. True rainforest species.
speciesNotes.ornata: Ornate Pacman Frog - Temperate South America. Standard tropical care. Most common in pet trade.
speciesNotes.aurita: Brazilian Horned Frog - Atlantic rainforest. Similar care to C. cornuta.
speciesNotes.hybrid: Fantasy Pacman Frog (C. cranwelli √ó C. cornuta hybrid) - Standard tropical care, various color morphs.

regions: South America: Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Bolivia, Uruguay, Colombia, Venezuela, Suriname
